conclusion: To solve the problem, analyze the v-t graph to determine the skydiver's vertical movement during the 0 to 10 seconds interval.
Calculate the distance fallen by integrating the velocity function over time.

The image shows a v-t (velocity-time) graph with a vertical axis labeled 'v/(m·s⁻¹)' and a horizontal axis labeled 't/s.' The graph starts at the origin, increases linearly to a peak at 10 seconds, and then decreases linearly to zero at 15 seconds.
The problem requires determining whether the distance fallen by the skydiver during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is greater than or less than 100 meters.
Identify the velocity function: The graph shows a linear increase in velocity from 0 to 20 m/s over the first 10 seconds, represented as v(t) = 2t.
Calculate the distance fallen by integrating the velocity function over the time interval from 0 to 10 seconds. The integral of v(t) = 2t is t². Evaluating this from 0 to 10 seconds gives 100 meters.
Compare the calculated distance of 100 meters with the threshold of 100 meters. The distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is exactly 100 meters.
